_88ValidRangeType.description: Valid range data value of a variable: minimum and maximum values. For example. '7500, -1', or '0, 377'.

___Min.description: Minimum data value of a variable.

___Max.description: Maximum data value of a variable.

_88TaggingType.description: The elements of this section apply to a variable.

___Tags.description: This element allows authors to provide words or phrases to further describe the data. These tags can be searched on in much the same way as science keywords but are sourced from a list specific to the science disipline of the variable

___TagsSource.description: This element allows authors to identify the source of the tags.

_88VariableTypeEnum.description: This element is used to identify the variable as a Science Variable or as a Quality Variable or as an Ancillary Variable. If a variable does not contain this field, it will be assumed to be a science variable.

_88ServiceTypeType.description: The elements of this section apply to a variable.

___ServiceType.description: This element enables specification of service type. The variable may not yet be available via a service. If so, which protocol standard? For example, 'WMS', 'WCS' etc.

$eref.description: This element enables specification of service type.

___Visualizable.description: A flag to indicate whether this variable is able to be visualized within the context of a service.

___Subsettable.description: A flag to indicate whether this variable is able to be subsetted within the context of a service.

_88ServiceTypeEnum.description: This element enables specification of service type.

_88CharacteristicsType.description: The elements of this section apply to a variable.

___Bounds.description: Describes the spatial bounds of a variable. Western Longitude, Northern Latitude and Eastern Longitude, Southern Latitude - often specified in decimal degrees. For example, 'UpperLeftPointMtrs = -180.0, 89.5; LowerRightMtrs = 177.5, -89.5.'

___SizeUnits.description: The computed byte size units for the variable, per the data field. For example B, KB, MB, GB.

___Reference.description: Provides a link to variable's reference documentation.

___ChunkSize.description: Describes the chunk size of a variable. For example, '100'.

___StandardName.description: The CF-compliant 'Standard Name' for the variable.

___Coordinates.description: A variable’s coordinates. These are used to describe how the variable is represented with respect to the Earth geoid.

___Size.description: The computed byte size for the variable, per the data field. Typically, this is the X dimension times the Y dimension times the number of bytes in the data type (8, 16, 32, etc.). For example, 1200 x 1200 x 16 = 23,040,000.

___GridMapping.description: The name of the mapping projection standard for the variable. For example: Mercator. This is sourced from the granule header. See the global attributes section.

___Structure.description: This is a string containing the structure of the variable. This is sourced from the granule header. See the variables section.

_88DataTypeEnum.description: This element is used to identify the data type of the variable.

$eref.description: This element is used to identify the data type of the variable.

___DataType.description: Specify data type of a variable. These types can be either: uint8, uint16, etc.

___ServiceType.description: The service information of a variable.

$eref.description: The elements of this section apply to a variable.

___ServiceType.description: This element enables specification of service type. The variable may not yet be available via a service. If so, which protocol standard? For example, 'WMS', 'WCS' etc.

___Visualizable.description: A flag to indicate whether this variable is able to be visualized within the context of a service.

___Subsettable.description: A flag to indicate whether this variable is able to be subsetted within the context of a service.

___Dimensions.description: The values of the dimensions of the variable represented in the data field. For example, '1200, 1200'. This is sourced from the granule header. See the dimensions section.

___Characteristics.description: The characteristics of a variable.  The elements of this section apply to a Variable.

$eref.description: The elements of this section apply to a variable.

___Bounds.description: Describes the spatial bounds of a variable. Western Longitude, Northern Latitude and Eastern Longitude, Southern Latitude - often specified in decimal degrees. For example, 'UpperLeftPointMtrs = -180.0, 89.5; LowerRightMtrs = 177.5, -89.5.'

___SizeUnits.description: The computed byte size units for the variable, per the data field. For example B, KB, MB, GB.

___Reference.description: Provides a link to variable's reference documentation.

___ChunkSize.description: Describes the chunk size of a variable. For example, '100'.

___StandardName.description: The CF-compliant 'Standard Name' for the variable.

___Coordinates.description: A variable’s coordinates. These are used to describe how the variable is represented with respect to the Earth geoid.

___Size.description: The computed byte size for the variable, per the data field. Typically, this is the X dimension times the Y dimension times the number of bytes in the data type (8, 16, 32, etc.). For example, 1200 x 1200 x 16 = 23,040,000.

___GridMapping.description: The name of the mapping projection standard for the variable. For example: Mercator. This is sourced from the granule header. See the global attributes section.

___Structure.description: This is a string containing the structure of the variable. This is sourced from the granule header. See the variables section.

___FillValueDescription.description: Description of the  fill value of the variable in the data file.

$eref.description: Valid range data value of a variable: minimum and maximum values. For example. '7500, -1', or '0, 377'.

___Min.description: Minimum data value of a variable.

___Max.description: Maximum data value of a variable.

___ValidRange.description: Valid range data value of a variable: minimum and maximum values. For example. '7500, -1', or '0, 377'.

___Units.description: The units associated with a variable.

$eref.description: The expanded or long name related to the short name.

___LongName.description: The descriptive name for the variable.

___DimensionsName.description: The names of the dimensions of the variable represented in the data field. For example, '1200, 1200'. This is sourced from the granule header. See the dimensions section.

___ScienceKeywords.description: Controlled Science Keywords describing the collection.  The controlled vocabulary for Science Keywords is maintained in the Keyword Management System (KMS).

$eref.description: Enables specification of Earth science keywords related to the collection.  The Earth Science keywords are chosen from a controlled keyword hierarchy maintained in the Keyword Management System (KMS).

___Offset.description: The physical value corresponding to a cell value of zero. For example, '0.49'.

___Tagging.description: The tagging information of a variable.

$eref.description: The elements of this section apply to a variable.

___Tags.description: This element allows authors to provide words or phrases to further describe the data. These tags can be searched on in much the same way as science keywords but are sourced from a list specific to the science disipline of the variable

___TagsSource.description: This element allows authors to identify the source of the tags.

___Scale.description: Scale factor which has been applied to the cell value. For example, '0.002'

$eref.description: This element is used to identify the variable as a Science Variable or as a Quality Variable or as an Ancillary Variable. If a variable does not contain this field, it will be assumed to be a science variable.

___VariableType.description: Specify basic type of a variable. These types can be either: Science, Ancillary, Quality etc.

___FillValue.description: The fill value of the variable in the data file. It is generally a value which falls outside the valid range. For example, if the valid range is '0, 360', the fill value may be '377'.
